+'''Stephanie Bice''' (née '''Asady'''; born November 11, 1973) is an American politician, the first Iranian American elected to Congress.<ref>{{cite web
  | last = Bice
  | first = Stephanie
  | title =  Stephanie Bice Candidate U.S. House of Representatives (R-5th/OK)
  | url = http://www.iranianamericanpac.org/stephanie-bice.aspx
  | access-date = November 5, 2020 }}</ref> Her father was an Iranian immigrant named Hosein Asady, also known as Joe Asady.<ref>{{cite web
  | last = Rand
  | first = Ayan
  | title =  Ayn Rand Was Right
  | url = https://ymlp.com/zGVCfu
  | access-date = November 5, 2020 }}</ref> She has served in the [[Oklahoma Senate]] from the 22nd district since 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newsok.com/article/4949182/on-the-ballot-oklahoma-senate-district-22 |title=On the ballot: Oklahoma Senate District 22 |publisher=Newsok.com |date=June 21, 2014 |accessdate=December 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oksenate.gov/Senators/biographies/bice_bio.aspx |title=Senator Stephanie Bice - District 22 |publisher=Oksenate.gov |date= |accessdate=December 28, 2018}}</ref> She is the Representative-elect for {{ushr|OK|5}} after defeating incumbent Democrat [[Kendra Horn]] in the [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Oklahoma|2020 election]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Live: Oklahoma State Primary Election Results 2020|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/06/30/us/elections/results-oklahoma-primary-elections.html|access-date=July 1, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
 
 ==Education and early career==
 Born in [[Oklahoma City]], Bice graduated from [[Oklahoma State University–Stillwater|Oklahoma State University]] with a bachelor's degree in marketing and a minor in international business.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Snyder |first1=Dan |title=Meet the candidate: Stephanie Bice (R-OK5) |url=https://okcfox.com/news/election/meet-the-candidate-stephanie-bice-r-ok5 |work=KOKH |date=June 17, 2020}}</ref>
 
 Bice worked for eight years in financial oversight, business strategy and marketing for her family's technology company in [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]]. She later helped lead a boutique digital marketing agency in Oklahoma City as vice president of business development.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Forman |first1=Carmen |title=Outlook 2020: Bice played a key role in bringing Oklahoma into the modern liquor era |url=https://oklahoman.com/article/5658428/outlook-2020-bice-played-a-key-role-in-bringing-oklahoma-into-the-modern-liquor-era |accessdate=October 13, 2020 |work=Oklahoman.com |date=April 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bice announces bid |url=https://yukonprogressnews.com/2019/04/26/bice-announces-bid/ |accessdate=October 13, 2020 |work=Yukon Progress |date=April 26, 2019}}</ref>

 '''Yvette Herrell'''<ref name="PVS">{{Cite web |title=Yvette Herrell's Biography |url=https://justfacts.votesmart.org/candidate/biography/121681/yvette-herrell |access-date=April 3, 2020 |publisher=[[Project Vote Smart]]}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] politician, businesswoman, and real estate agent who is the Representative-elect for [[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district]]. She previously served as a member of the [[New Mexico House of Representatives]] for District 51 from January 18, 2011 until January 15, 2019.<ref name="NML">{{Cite web |title=Representative Yvette Herrell (R) |url=http://www.nmlegis.gov/lcs/legislator_details.aspx?SPONCODE=HHERY |access-date=February 12, 2014 |publisher=[[New Mexico Legislature]] |location=[[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]}}</ref>
 
 Herrell was the Republican nominee for [[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district]] in the 2018 elections. She was defeated by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Xochitl Torres Small]]. Herrell again became the Republican nominee for the [[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district|2nd district]] in 2020, defeating [[Xochitl Torres Small|Torres Small]] in the November general election.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Edmondson|first=Catie|date=2020-11-04|title=Yvette Herrell Ousts Xochitl Torres Small From New Mexico House Seat|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/04/us/politics/new-mexico-yvette-herrell.html|access-date=2020-11-04|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> She is the third Native American woman elected to Congress, the second Native woman from New Mexico and the first Republican Native Woman.
 
 == Early life and education ==
 Born in [[Ruidoso, New Mexico]], Herrell is a member of the [[Cherokee Nation]].<ref name="native">{{Cite web |last=Olmstead |first=Mallory |date=November 6, 2018 |title=Two Native American Women Become First Elected to Congress |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/11/sharice-davids-deb-haaland-first-native-american-women-elected-congress.html |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]}}</ref><ref>[http://tn--npta2.www3.capwiz.com/bio/id/65799]</ref> After attending Cloudcroft High School, Herrell earned a legal secretary diploma from the [[ITT Technical Institute]] School of Business in [[Boise, Idaho]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Candidate |first=The |title=2nd Congressional District candidate Yvette Herrell |url=https://www.abqjournal.com/1167038/2nd-congressional-district-candidate-yvette-herrell.html |access-date=2020-06-03 |website=www.abqjournal.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Candidate |first=The |title=Q&A: Congressional District 2 Yvette Herrell |url=https://www.abqjournal.com/1451187/qa-congressional-district-2-yvette-herrell.html |access-date=2020-06-03 |website=www.abqjournal.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Barbati |first=Duane |title=Yvette Herrell running for Congressional seat vacated by Pearce |url=https://www.alamogordonews.com/story/news/local/community/2017/07/12/yvette-herrell-running-congressional-seat-vacated-pearce/470703001/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Alamogordo Daily News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Devine |first=Jacqueline |title=Incumbent Herrell looking to retain state District 51 seat |url=https://www.alamogordonews.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/20/incumbent-herrell-looking-retain-state-district-51-seat/92480262/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Alamogordo Daily News |language=en}}</ref>
 
 == Career ==
 Since graduating from the [[ITT Technical Institute]], Herrell has worked as a realtor in [[Alamogordo, New Mexico]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Yvette Herrell |url=https://ballotpedia.org/Yvette_Herrell |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Ballotpedia |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=YVETTE HERRELL {{!}} New Mexico REALTORS® |url=https://www.newmexicohomesearch.com/agents/yvette-herrell/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=www.newmexicohomesearch.com}}</ref>

 Born in [[Ruidoso, New Mexico]], Herrell is a member of the [[Cherokee Nation]].<ref name="native">{{Cite web |last=Olmstead |first=Mallory |date=November 6, 2018 |title=Two Native American Women Become First Elected to Congress |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/11/sharice-davids-deb-haaland-first-native-american-women-elected-congress.html |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]}}</ref><ref>[http://tn--npta2.www3.capwiz.com/bio/id/65799]</ref> After attending Cloudcroft High School, Herrell earned a legal secretary diploma from the [[ITT Technical Institute]] School of Business in [[Boise, Idaho]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Candidate |first=The |title=2nd Congressional District candidate Yvette Herrell |url=https://www.abqjournal.com/1167038/2nd-congressional-district-candidate-yvette-herrell.html |access-date=2020-06-03 |website=www.abqjournal.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Candidate |first=The |title=Q&A: Congressional District 2 Yvette Herrell |url=https://www.abqjournal.com/1451187/qa-congressional-district-2-yvette-herrell.html |access-date=2020-06-03 |website=www.abqjournal.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Barbati |first=Duane |title=Yvette Herrell running for Congressional seat vacated by Pearce |url=https://www.alamogordonews.com/story/news/local/community/2017/07/12/yvette-herrell-running-congressional-seat-vacated-pearce/470703001/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Alamogordo Daily News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Devine |first=Jacqueline |title=Incumbent Herrell looking to retain state District 51 seat |url=https://www.alamogordonews.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/20/incumbent-herrell-looking-retain-state-district-51-seat/92480262/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Alamogordo Daily News |language=en}}</ref>

 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Alaska''' was held on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019|archive-date=January 3, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190103202343/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Alaska]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Alaska has 3 electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019|archive-date=January 9, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190109144218/https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 By the time that the primary elections were held in Alaska on April 10, 2020, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] was already the Republican Party's [[presumptive nominee]], being the only viable declared major candidate left. On the Democratic Party's side, former [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] became the presumptive nominee on April 8, 2020 after [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Bernie Sanders]] dropped out. The Libertarian Party, which received over 5% of the vote in [[2016 United States presidential election in Alaska|2016]], has nominated [[Jo Jorgensen]].

 ==District 7==
 {{see also|Georgia's 7th congressional district}}
 The 7th district covers the northeast [[Atlanta metropolitan area]], encompassing almost all of [[Gwinnett County, Georgia|Gwinnett]] and [[Forsyth County, Georgia|Forsyth]] counties. It includes the cities of [[Peachtree Corners, Georgia|Peachtree Corners]], [[Norcross, Georgia|Norcross]], [[Cumming, Georgia|Cumming]], [[Lawrenceville, Georgia|Lawrenceville]], [[Duluth, Georgia|Duluth]], [[Snellville, Georgia|Snellville]], [[Suwanee, Georgia|Suwanee]], and [[Buford, Georgia|Buford]]. The incumbent is Republican [[Rob Woodall]], who was re-elected with 50.1% of the vote in 2018,<ref name="HPVT" /> and subsequently announced he would not seek re-election on February 7, 2019.<ref name="GA07Woodall">{{cite news|last1=Hallerman|first1=Tamar|title=U.S. Rep. Rob Woodall will not seek re-election|url=https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/breaking-rep-rob-woodall-will-not-seek-reelection/TIJuFbzQAONPQyuBLulcJK/|newspaper=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|date=February 7, 2019|accessdate=February 15, 2019|archive-date=February 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190215161940/https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/breaking-rep-rob-woodall-will-not-seek-reelection/TIJuFbzQAONPQyuBLulcJK/|url-status=live}}</ref>

[[Yale University]] ([[Master of Theological Studies|MAR]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|https://coons.senate.gov|Senate website}} }} '''Christopher Andrew Coons''' (born September 9, 1963) is an American politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|junior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Delaware]] since 2010. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], Coons served as the [[county executive]] of [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]] from 2005 to 2010. He was the 1983 [[Truman Scholar]] from Delaware, and the first recipient of the award to serve in the United States Senate. -Raised in [[Hockessin, Delaware]], Coons graduated from [[Amherst College]] in [[Massachusetts]], where he joined Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity. He received graduate degrees from [[Yale Divinity School]] and [[Yale Law School]]. He went to work as a volunteer [[relief worker]] in Kenya, where he had taken classes in the [[University of Nairobi]], later returning to the U.S. to work for the [[Coalition for the Homeless]] in New York. He spent some time as a legal clerk in New York before returning to Delaware in 1996, where he spent eight years as in-house counsel for a materials manufacturing company. In the interim he worked for several nonprofit organizations. +Raised in [[Hockessin, Delaware]], Coons graduated from [[Amherst College]] in [[Massachusetts]], where he joined [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] Fraternity. He received graduate degrees from [[Yale Divinity School]] and [[Yale Law School]]. He went to work as a volunteer [[relief worker]] in Kenya, where he had taken classes in the [[University of Nairobi]], later returning to the U.S. to work for the [[Coalition for the Homeless]] in New York. He spent some time as a legal clerk in New York before returning to Delaware in 1996, where he spent eight years as in-house counsel for a materials manufacturing company. In the interim he worked for several nonprofit organizations. Coons served as president of the [[New Castle County Council]] from 2001 to 2005 and county executive of [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]] from 2005 to 2010. He balanced the county budget with a surplus in fiscal year 2010 by cutting spending and raising taxes, and the county maintained a [[Fitch Group|AAA bond rating]]. Coons contested the [[2010 United States Senate special election in Delaware|2010 Senate special election for Delaware]]. He defeated the Republican nominee, [[Christine O'Donnell]], to succeed [[Ted Kaufman]], who had been appointed to the seat when [[Joe Biden]] resigned to become [[Vice President of the United States]]. He was elected to a full term [[United States Senate election in Delaware, 2014|in 2014]]. Coons is the vice chair of the [[United States Senate Committee on Ethics|Senate Ethics Committee]]. His other committee assignments include [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations]], [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Foreign Relations]], [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary]], and [[United States Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship|Small Business and Entrepreneurship]]. He previously served as ranking member of the [[United States Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on African Affairs|Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on African Affairs]] and the [[United States Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Bankruptcy and the Courts|Judiciary Subcommittee on Bankruptcy and the Courts]].{{cite web|url=https://www.coons.senate.gov/about |title=Chris Coons Biography |publisher=www.coons.senate.gov |accessdate=December 19, 2017}} Coons was the co-chair for the 2019 [[National Prayer Breakfast]]. He previously co-chaired the 2017 National Prayer Breakfast, and co-chairs the weekly Senate Prayer Breakfast.{{cite web|url= http://time.com/5137579/national-prayer-breakfast-lankford-coons/|title=National Prayer Breakfast Co-Chairs Named |publisher=www.time.com |accessdate=February 14, 2018}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' called Coons an "effective" emissary of [[Joe Biden]] to former and current Republican lawmakers in Biden's [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign|2020]] campaign for president.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/06/us/politics/trump-biden-republicans-voters.html|title=Bush, Romney and Powell wouldn't back Trump re-election|work=The New York Times}} ==Early life and education== Coons was born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], the son of Sarah Louise "Sally" (née Ives) and Kenelm Winslow "Ken" Coons. His ancestry includes English and Irish.{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/senators/coons.htm |title=Chris Coons ancestry |publisher=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |accessdate=October 8, 2012}} Coons grew up in [[Hockessin, Delaware]], where he attended the public Yorklyn Elementary School and later H.B. DuPont Middle School. His parents struggled financially and divorced in the mid 1970s. He and his two brothers lived with their mother for a few years until 1977, when his mother married [[Robert W. Gore]], the President of [[W. L. Gore and Associates]].{{cite news |last1=Hale |first1=Charlotte |title=Strong on Service |work=The News Journal (Wilmington, Delaware) |date=October 15, 2004 |page=B1 & B5}} He graduated from the private [[Tower Hill School]] and then [[Amherst College]] in 1985 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[chemistry]] and [[political science]]. While in college, he was a member of [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] fraternity (Sigma chapter) and a U.S. Senate intern. In 1983, Coons was awarded the [[Truman Scholarship]]. During his junior year of college, he studied abroad at the [[University of Nairobi]] in [[Kenya]] through [[St. Lawrence University]]'s Kenya Semester Program.{{cite web |url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/08/02/look-st-lawrence-universitys-study-abroad-program-kenya |title=St. Lawrence University's Kenya Semester Program |publisher=www.insidehighered.com |date= |accessdate=December 27, 2017}} In 1992, he earned a master's degree in ethics from [[Yale Divinity School]] and a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from [[Yale Law School]].{{cite web |url=http://www.chriscoons.com/about/meet_chris_coons |title=Meet Chris Coons |accessdate=December 27, 2017 |publisher=Chris Coons for U.S. Senate}} (campaign web site biography) In 2018, Delaware State University named Coons as an Honorary Doctor in Humane Letters. ==Professional career== After college, Coons worked in [[Washington, D.C.]], for the Investor Responsibility Research Center, where he wrote a book on South Africa and the U.S. [[Disinvestment from South Africa|divestment movement]]. He then worked as a volunteer for the [[South African Council of Churches]] and as a [[relief worker]] in Kenya, before returning to the U.S. to work for the National Coalition for the Homeless in New York. In 1992, he earned a J.D. degree from [[Yale Law School]], and a master's degree in [[ethics]] from [[Yale Divinity School]].{{Cite news|title = Castle vs. Coons| author=Yearick, Bob| work = Delaware Today | date = June 15, 2010| url =http://www.delawaretoday.com/Delaware-Today/July-2010/Castle-vs-Coons/index.php?cparticle=3&siarticle=2#artanc| accessdate = September 16, 2010}} Coons clerked for [[Federal Judge|Judge]] [[Jane Richards Roth]] on the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]], and then worked for the National "I Have a Dream" Foundation in New York.{{Cite news| title = Chris Coons: Delaware's surprise favorite| publisher = CNN| date = September 15, 2010| url = http://articles.cnn.com/2010-09-15/politics/coons.profile_1_chris-coons-election-delaware?_s=PM:POLITICS| accessdate = September 16, 2010| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100917035256/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-09-15/politics/coons.profile_1_chris-coons-election-delaware?_s=PM:POLITICS| archive-date = September 17, 2010| url-status = dead}} After returning to Delaware in 1996, Coons began his eight-year career as in-house counsel for [[W.L. Gore & Associates]], Inc., [[Newark, Delaware]]-based makers of [[Gore-Tex]] fabrics and other high-tech materials. There he was responsible for the ethics training program, federal government relations, e-commerce legal work, and for general commercial contracting.

A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he was the [[United States Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama|Northern District of Alabama]] from 1997 to 2001. Jones was born in [[Fairfield, Alabama]], and is a graduate of the [[University of Alabama]] and [[Cumberland School of Law]] at [[Samford University]]. After law school, he worked as a congressional staffer and as a federal prosecutor before moving to private practice. In 1997, President [[Bill Clinton]] appointed Jones as U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama. Jones's most prominent cases were the successful prosecution of two [[Ku Klux Klan]] members for the [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing|1963 Birmingham church bombing]] that killed four African-American girls and the indictment of domestic terrorist [[Eric Rudolph]]. He returned to private practice at the conclusion of Clinton's presidency in 2001. Jones announced his candidacy for United States Senate in the [[2017 United States Senate special election in Alabama|2017 special election]] following the resignation of Republican incumbent [[Jeff Sessions]] to become [[United States Attorney General|U.S. Attorney General]]. After winning the Democratic primary in August, he faced former [[Supreme Court of Alabama|Alabama Supreme Court]] Justice [[Roy Moore]] in the general election. Jones was considered a long-shot candidate in a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|deeply Republican state]]. A month before the election, Moore was [[Roy Moore sexual misconduct allegations|alleged]] to have sexually assaulted and otherwise acted inappropriately with several females, including some who were minors at the time.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/dec/12/roy-moore-loses-alabama-senate-race-doug-jones-wins|title=Alabama election: Democrats triumph over Roy Moore in major blow to Trump |last1=Jacobs |first1=Ben |last2=Smith |first2=David |date=December 13, 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=August 6, 2018}} Jones won the special election by 22,000 votes, 50%–48%.{{cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/turbulent-senate-race-now-hands-alabama-voters-51733556 |title=Democrat Jones wins stunning red-state Alabama Senate upset |author1=Chandler, Kim |date=December 13, 2017 |publisher=ABC News |agency=Associated Press |author2=Peoples, Steve |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171217005217/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/turbulent-senate-race-now-hands-alabama-voters-51733556 |archive-date=December 17, 2017 |url-status=dead }} Jones is currently the only statewide elected Democrat in Alabama and the first Democrat to win statewide office since [[Lucy Baxley]] was elected President of the [[Alabama Public Service Commission]] in 2008. Democrats had not represented Alabama in the U.S. Senate since 1997, when [[Howell Heflin]] left office. Jones is considered a moderate Democrat who demonstrates a willingness to work with Republicans and split with his party on certain issues.{{cite web |last1=Beaman |first1=Jeremy |title=Sen. Doug Jones has proved himself — so far — to be a moderate Democrat |url=https://yellowhammernews.com/sen-doug-jones-has-proved-himself-so-far-to-be-a-moderate-democrat/ |website=YellowHammer News |website=Politico |date=Nov 7, 2020}} ==Early life and education== Doug Jones was born in [[Fairfield, Alabama]] to Gordon and Gloria (Wesson) Jones.{{cite web|url=http://dougjonesforsenate.com/|title=Meet Doug Jones": "Doug's parents, Gordon and Gloria Jones, live in Birmingham and his sister Terrie Savage and her husband Scott live in Hartselle.|publisher=Doug Jones for Senate|date=August 16, 2017|accessdate=August 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212011108/https://dougjonesforsenate.com/|archive-date=December homemaker.{{Citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/05/us/public-lives-an-alabama-prosecutor-confronts-the-burden-of-history.html|title=PUBLIC LIVES; An Alabama Prosecutor Confronts the Burden St. U. L. Rev.]] 781, 782 n.2 (1999). On September 8, 1997, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama appointed Jones as interim U.S. Attorney. The [[United States Senate|Senate]] confirmed Jones's nomination on November 8, 1997, by [[voice vote]].{{cite news |first=John |last=Verhoevek |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/alabama-senate-race-pits-doug-jones-roy-moore/story?id=50127528 |title=Meet the Alabama Senate candidates: Controversial gun-toting judge Roy Moore and a lawyer who fought the KKK |publisher=ABC News |date=September 27, 2017}} In January 1998, [[Eric Rudolph]] bombed the New Woman All Women Health Care Center in Birmingham. Jones was responsible for coordinating the state and federal task force in the aftermath, and advocated that Rudolph be tried first in Birmingham before being extradited and tried in Georgia for his crimes in that state, such as the [[Centennial Olympic Park bombing]].{{Cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=90596&page=1|title=Bombing Suspect Eric Rudolph Indicted|date=November 15, 2000|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/03/us/bombing-suspect-is-moved-to-alabama-for-trial-there-first.html|title=Bombing Suspect Is Moved to Alabama, for Trial There First|last=Gettlman|first=Jeffrey|date=June 3, 2003|newspaper=The New York Times}} ===16th Street Baptist Church bombing case=== [[File:Doug Jones Cherry Trial (cropped).jpg|thumb|150px|Jones during the trial of Bobby Frank Cherry]] Jones prosecuted [[Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr.]] and [[Bobby Frank Cherry]], two members of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], for their roles in the 1963 [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]]. The case was reopened the year before Jones was appointed, but did not gain traction until his appointment. A [[federal grand jury]] was called in 1998, which caught the attention of Cherry's ex-wife, Willadean Cherry, and led her to call the FBI to give her testimony. Willadean then introduced Jones to family and friends, who reported their own experiences from the time of the bombing. A key piece of evidence was a tape from the time of the bombing in which Blanton said he had plotted with others to make the bomb. Jones was deputized to argue in state court and indicted Blanton and Cherry in 2000.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/25/us/church-bombing-trial-begins-birmingham-city-s-past-very-much-present.html|title=As Church Bombing Trial Begins in Birmingham, the City's Past Is Very Much Present|last=Sack|first=Kevin|date=April 25, 2001 |newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://articles.latimes.com/2013/sep/14/nation/la-na-nn-birmingham-bombing-prosecutor-20130913|title=Prosecutor reflects on 50th anniversary of 1963 Birmingham bombing|last=Hennessy-Fiske|first=Molly|date=September 14, 2013 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=May 18, 2017}} Blanton was found guilty in 2001 and Cherry in 2002. Both were sentenced to life in prison. Blanton was up for parole in 2016; Jones spoke against his release, and parole was denied. Cherry died in prison in 2004.{{Cite news |url=http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2016/08/alabama_board_considering_paro.html|title=16th Street Baptist Church bomber Thomas Blanton denied parole|last=Faulk|first=Kent|date=August 3, 2016|newspaper=[[The Birmingham News]] |accessdate=May 18, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A61428-2004Nov18.html|title=Birmingham Bomber Bobby Frank Cherry Dies in Prison at 74|last=Lamb|first=Yvonne|date=November 19, 2004|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 18, 2017}} {{external media| float = left| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?457874-1/after-words-senator-doug-jones ''After Words'' interview with Jones on ''Bending Toward Justice'', March 9, 2019], [[C-SPAN]]}}

Steve Bullock to run for Senate|date=2020-03-09|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-09}}</ref>
+On March 4, 2020, after months of speculation and denials from Bullock himself, ''The New York Times'' reported that Bullock would enter Montana's U.S. Senate [[2020 United States Senate election in Montana|election]] to challenge Republican incumbent [[Steve Daines]]. The move came after Senate Minority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] (D-NY) flew to Montana to persuade Bullock to run and after Bullock talked with former president [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Steve Bullock Is Running for Senate in Montana|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/04/us/politics/steve-bullock-montana-senate.html|last=Martin|first=Jonathan|work=New York Times|accessdate=March 4, 2020}}</ref> Both believed that he was the only formidable candidate against Daines.<ref>{{cite news|title= Schumer meets with Bullock as Montana filing deadline for Senate seat nears|url= https://www.politico.com/amp/news/2020/02/25/schumer-meets-bullock-montana-senate-seat-117479|last=Everett|first=Burgess|publisher=Politico|accessdate=March 10, 2020}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2020}} Bullock ran for the seat formerly held for six terms by Democrat [[Max Baucus]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2020-03-09/senior-adviser-montana-gov-steve-bullock-to-run-for-senate|title=Montana Gov. Steve Bullock to run for Senate|date=2020-03-09|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-09}}</ref>
 
 Bullock officially declared his candidacy on March 9, 2020, the last day to file.<ref>https://twitter.com/stevebullockmt/status/1236986586606100481</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2020/3/9/21166028/steve-bullock-montana-senate-race-democrats|title=Gov. Steve Bullock just made the Montana Senate race competitive for Democrats|publisher=Vox|date=March 8, 2020}}</ref> The announcement prompted all other candidates for the Democratic nomination except one to drop out and endorse Bullock. This included the mayor of Helena, [[Wilmot Collins]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Collins |first1=Wilmot |title=Thank you, Montana. It's been my honor to run for U.S. Senate. Today I'm suspending my campaign and endorsing Governor Steve Bullock. |url=https://twitter.com/CollinsWilmot/status/1237147675054600192 |website=@CollinsWilmot |accessdate=9 March 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Neumann|first=Cora|title=Cora Neumann withdraws from Montana senate race, endorses Steve Bullock|url= https://mobile.twitter.com/CoraforMT/status/1237028772018180097|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=March 9, 2020}}</ref><ref>https://mobile.twitter.com/KnolesMichael/status/1236997949730611207</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Stein |first1=Perrin |title=Bozeman Senate candidate drops out of race, supports Bullock |url=https://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/politics/bozeman-senate-candidate-drops-out-of-race-supports-bullock/article_548ab9a5-c981-50c1-a3b4-044e0ec54df2.html |website=Bozeman Daily Chronicle}}</ref> On June 2, 2020, Bullock won the Democratic primary<ref>https://sosmt.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020PrimaryReportStateCanvass.pdf</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/06/02/us/elections/results-montana-senate-primary-election.html|title=Montana U.S. Senate Primary Election Results|date=June 24, 2020|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> with 94.8% of the vote to challenger John Mues's 2.8%.{{cn|date=November 2020}} On November 3, 2020, Bullock lost to Daines in the general election.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/524126-daines-fends-off-challenge-to-win-second-montana-senate-term|title=Daines fends off challenge to win second Montana Senate term|first=Regina|last=Zilbermints|date=November 4, 2020|website=TheHill}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/04/montana-senate-election-results-2020-433588|title=Daines holds Montana Senate seat for GOP|first=Burgess|last=Everett|website=POLITICO}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nbcmontana.com/news/beyond-the-podium/ap-daines-wins-reelection-in-montana|title=AP: Daines wins re-election in Montana|first=The Associated|last=Press|date=November 3, 2020|website=KECI}}</ref>
 
 == Political positions ==
 Bullock has been described by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[ABC News]]'' as a [[moderate Democrat]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/montana-gov-steve-bullock-considering-2020-white-house-bid-now-says-he-supports-assault-weapons-ban/2018/08/19/58f4a34c-a3f8-11e8-a656-943eefab5daf_story.html|title=Montana Gov. Steve Bullock, considering 2020 White House bid, says he supports assault weapons ban|last=Sonmez|first=Felicia|date=August 19, 2018|website=washingtonpost.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181207091850/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/montana-gov-steve-bullock-considering-2020-white-house-bid-now-says-he-supports-assault-weapons-ban/2018/08/19/58f4a34c-a3f8-11e8-a656-943eefab5daf_story.html|archive-date=December 7, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/red-state-governor-democrats-lose-midterms-referendum-donald/story?id=57477278|title=Democratic governor of Montana says 'no secret recipe' as he eyes 2020|date=August 29, 2018|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=December 8, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181209124148/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/red-state-governor-democrats-lose-midterms-referendum-donald/story?id=57477278|archive-date=December 9, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> ''[[The New York Times]]'' referred to Bullock as being among [[Centrism|centrist]] Democratic governors.<ref name=NYTimes17July2017>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/17/us/politics/democrat-governors-bullock-mcauliffe.html|title=As Party Drifts Left, Pragmatic Democratic Governors Have Eye on White House|last=Martin|first=Jonathan|date=July 17, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=December 8, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190129073634/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/17/us/politics/democrat-governors-bullock-mcauliffe.html|archive-date=January 29, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> [[On the Issues|On The Issues]], which tracks candidates' positions and records, also classifies Bullock as a "Moderate Liberal."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Steve_Bullock.htm|title=Steve Bullock on the Issues|website=www.ontheissues.org|access-date=January 21, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107202331/http://www.ontheissues.org/Steve_Bullock.htm|archive-date=November 7, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ===Abortion===
 In 2017, Bullock vetoed measures to outlaw [[abortion]]s after 20 weeks, citing constitutional rulings on the women's ability to protect their lives and health and arguing that elected officials should not put personal beliefs above medical professionals' judgment.<ref>{{cite web |title=Abortion, guns, state plane among bills vetoed by governor |url=https://apnews.com/article/3cd844d6f8f643c897d132c930f19379 |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=5 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Governor Bullock Stands With Montana Families By Vetoing Extreme Bills Endangering Women|url=https://www.aclumontana.org/en/press-releases/governor-bullock-stands-montana-families-vetoing-extreme-bills-endangering-women|website=American Civil Liberties Union of Montana|accessdate=July 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180702093732/https://www.aclumontana.org/en/press-releases/governor-bullock-stands-montana-families-vetoing-extreme-bills-endangering-women|archive-date=July 2, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> He has said that he personally believes life begins at [[Fetal viability|viability]] but that "it's not up to people like me to be making these decisions".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Frazin |first1=Rachel |title=2020 Dem Steve Bullock: I think life begins at viability |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/444444-bullock-i-think-life-begins-at-viability |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |language=en |date=19 May 2019}}</ref> In 2018, Bullock wrote a letter to [[Secretary of Health and Human Services]] [[Alex Azar]] requesting that [[Title X]] funding for reproductive health care and [[family planning]] for low-income women remain in effect, saying the program had generated more than $29 million in savings.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Drake |first1=Phil |title=Bullock repeats opposition to family planning changes |url=https://eu.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/2018/08/03/montana-governor-opposes-trumps-family-planning-changes/900103002/ |website=[[Great Falls Tribune]] |date=August 3, 2018}}</ref>
 
 ===Campaign finance reform===
 As Attorney General of Montana, Bullock advocated on behalf of the state's century-old ban on corporate money in elections, the Montana Corrupt Practices Act of 1912. After that and similar laws were struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court's ''[[Citizens United]]'' decision in 2010, Bullock countered with a new case, ''American Tradition Partnership, Inc. v. Bullock'' (2012). The Supreme Court disposed of the case in a 5–4 decision,<ref>{{cite web |title=AMERICAN TRADITION PARTNERSHIP, INC. v. BULLOCK |url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/11-1179 |website=Legal Information Institute |publisher=Cornell Law School |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904192224/https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/11-1179 |archive-date=September 4, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> but Bullock continued to advocate for campaign finance reform throughout his time as governor of Montana.<ref name="Billings Gazette">{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Charles S. |title=Bullock signs Montana campaign finance bill into law |url=https://billingsgazette.com/news/government-and-politics/bullock-signs-montana-campaign-finance-bill-into-law/article_c8a0cc59-a7bf-5381-9136-ae118d9a13ff.html |website=Billings Gazette |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904191908/https://billingsgazette.com/news/government-and-politics/bullock-signs-montana-campaign-finance-bill-into-law/article_c8a0cc59-a7bf-5381-9136-ae118d9a13ff.html |archive-date=September 4, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Memoli |first1=Mike |title=Montana governor pushes for more transparency on donors |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/card/montana-governor-pushes-more-transparency-donors-n880316 |website=NBC News |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180905052524/https://www.nbcnews.com/card/montana-governor-pushes-more-transparency-donors-n880316 |archive-date=September 5, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 In 2015, Bullock steered the DISCLOSE Act, a bipartisan campaign finance reform bill that bolstered disclosure requirements in Montana elections, through a GOP-controlled state legislature.<ref name="Billings Gazette"/><ref>{{Cite AV media |people=Soboroff, Jacob |title=MSNBC's American Swamp: Governor Bullock leading the fight against dark money in politics |medium=Video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uyL2h8e0CNI |publisher=Steve Bullock <!-- Official YouTube account --> |location= |date=July 29, 2019 |time= }}</ref>
 
 In June 2018, Bullock signed an executive order that required the recipients of major government contracts in Montana to disclose "[[dark money]] spending" in elections, including spending disclosure not explicitly required by federal law.<ref>{{cite web |agency=Associated Press |title=Bullock tells Montana contractors to report 'dark money' |url=https://coloradopolitics.com/out-west-roundup-bullock-tells-montana-contractors-report-dark-money/ |website=CP: Colorado Politics |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904192022/https://coloradopolitics.com/out-west-roundup-bullock-tells-montana-contractors-report-dark-money/ |archive-date=September 4, 2018 |url-status=live  }}</ref>

 ''[[The Atlantic]]'' called him the "secret diplomatic weapon" deployed against some of the thorniest foreign policy challenges of the US.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kralev|first1=Nicholas|title=The White House's Secret Diplomatic Weapon|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/04/the-white-houses-secret-diplomatic-weapon/274655/|accessdate=30 June 2014|work=The Atlantic|date=April 4, 2013}}</ref>
 
 === Carnegie Endowment for International Peace ===
 Burns was appointed the ninth President of the [[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]] on February 4, 2015, where he leads a global network of 140 scholars across 20 countries and six centers.
 
 Burns was widely assumed to be on the shortlist of the nominees of presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] for Secretary of State,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/hillary-clinton-john-kerry-secretary-state-226740|title=Would Hillary keep John Kerry on?|first=Michael|last=Crowley|website=POLITICO}}</ref> and is reported by POLITICO to be a possible contender for presidential candidate [[Joe Biden]]'s Secretary of State as well.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Toosi |first1=Nahal |title=The race to be Biden’s secretary of State is already underway |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/19/joe-biden-secretary-of-state-430089 |website=POLITICO |accessdate=19 October 2020 |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ===Publications===
 His bestselling memoir, ''[https://carnegieendowment.org/2019/01/25/back-channel-memoir-of-american-diplomacy-and-case-for-its-renewal-pub-78072 The Back Channel: A Memoir of American Diplomacy and the Case for Its Renewal]'', was published by [[Random House]] in 2019. It was published in conjunction with an [https://carnegieendowment.org/publications/interactive/back-channel/ archive] of nearly 100 declassified diplomatic cables. For ''The Back Channel'', Burns received The Douglas Dillon Book Award for Books of Distinction on the Practice of American Diplomacy (2019).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academyofdiplomacy.org/recipient/william-burns/|title=William Burns|website=The American Academy of Diplomacy}}</ref> 
 
 In 2019, he was made a contributing writer at The Atlantic magazine.
 
 Burns writes regularly on US foreign policy and diplomacy for the ''New York Times'', ''Washington Post'', ''Foreign Affairs'', and other publications.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1014|title=William J. Burns|website=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace}}</ref>
 
-His Oxford dissertation was published in 1985 as [https://www.amazon.com/Economic-American-Policy-Toward-1955-1981/dp/0873958691 ''Economic Aid and American Policy Toward Egypt, 1955–1981''].
+His Oxford dissertation was published in 1985 as ''Economic Aid and American Policy Toward Egypt, 1955–1981''.
 
 == Awards ==
 Burns is the recipient of three [[President's Award for Distinguished Federal Civilian Service|Presidential Distinguished Service Awards]] and a number of [[Awards of the United States Department of State|Department of State awards]], including three [[Secretary's Distinguished Service Award]]s, the [[Secretary's Career Achievement Award]], the [[Awards of the United States Department of State#Charles E. Cobb Jr. Award for Initiative and Success in Trade Development|Charles E. Cobb, Jr. Ambassadorial Award for Initiative and Success in Trade Development]] (2006), the [[Awards of the United States Department of State#Robert C. Frasure Memorial Award|Robert C. Frasure Memorial Award]] (2005), and the [[Awards of the United States Department of State|James Clement Dunn Award]] (1991). He also received the [[Department of Defense Award for Distinguished Public Service]] (2014), the U.S. Intelligence Community Medallion (2014), and the Central Intelligence Agency's [[Agency Seal Medal]] (2014). 
 
 In 1994, Burns was named to [[TIME Magazine|''TIME'' Magazine]]'s lists of "50 Most Promising American Leaders Under Age 40" and "100 Most Promising Global Leaders Under Age 40".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://time.com/3618532/future-leaders-of-the-1990s/|title=What Happened to the 'Future Leaders' of the 1990s?|website=Time}}</ref>  He was named ''[[Foreign Policy]]''<nowiki/>'s "Diplomat of the Year" in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bill Burns Honored as Diplomat of the Year|url=http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2013/06/12/bill_burns_honored_as_diplomat_of_the_year|website=foreignpolicy.com|publisher=Foreign Policy|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>  He is the recipient of [[Anti-Defamation League]]'s Distinguished Statesman Award (2014),<ref>{{cite web|title=Deputy Secretary of State Bill Burns Presented with ADL Award|url=http://www.adl.org/press-center/press-releases/miscellaneous/deputy-secretary-of-state-bill-burns-presented-with-adl-award.html|website=www.adl.org|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref> the [[Middle East Institute]]'s Lifetime Achievement Award (2014), and the [[American Academy of Diplomacy]]'s Annenberg Award for Diplomatic Excellence (2015).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academyofdiplomacy.org/award/annenberg-excellence-in-diplomacy-award/|title=Walter and Leonore Annenberg Excellence in Diplomacy Award|website=The American Academy of Diplomacy}}</ref>
 
 Burns holds four honorary doctoral degrees and is a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.<ref name="auto"/> He is also an honorary Fellow, St. John's College, Oxford (from 2012).<ref>{{cite web|title=RAI in America|url=http://www.rai.ox.ac.uk/about/RAI-in-America|website=www.rai.ox.ac.uk|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>
 
 ===Foreign Government Decorations===
 * Commandeur, [[Legion of Honour]] (France)
 * Knight Commander, [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Order of Merit]] (Germany)
 * Grand Cordon, [[Order of the Rising Sun]] (Japan)
 * [[Marshall Scholarship|Marshall Medal]] (UK)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.marshallscholarship.org/the-scholarship/the-marshall-medal|title=The Marshall Medal - Marshall Scholarships|website=www.marshallscholarship.org}}</ref>
 * Commentadore,  [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic|Order of Merit]] (Italy)
 * First Order, [[Order of the Star of Jordan|Al Kawkab Medal]] (Jordan)

 === Campaign ===
 After one term in the House representing [[Santa Barbara County, California|Santa Barbara]] and [[San Luis Obispo County, California|San Luis Obispo]] counties, Huffington spent $8 million by the end of August and a total of $28 million during the entire campaign. He became wealthy off oil and gas. The race saw personal attacks on Huffington's wife, [[Arianna Huffington]], who was very involved in the race (the media dubbed her the "Sir Edmund Hillary of social climbing," according to ''[[The Almanac of American Politics]]'').
 
 Huffington was called a hypocrite for supporting [[Proposition 187]] and then breaking the law for employing illegal aliens, a story which came out in the race's final days.<ref>{{cite news |author=B. Drummond Ayres Jr. |date=October 27, 1994 |title=THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CALIFORNIA; Huffington Admits Hiring Illegal Alien |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/27/us/the-1994-campaign-california-huffington-admits-hiring-illegal-alien.html?pagewanted=1}}</ref> A grand total of $44 million was spent in the election. At the time, it was the most expensive campaign in a non-presidential election in American history. [[Chris Cillizza]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' named the election one of the nastiest senate elections in modern history.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Chris Cillizza]] |date=July 1, 2010 |title=The 10 nastiest Senate races |publisher=The Washington Post The Fix blog |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/thefix/senate/the-10-nastiest-senate-races.html?wprss=thefix}}</ref>
 
 === Results ===
 On election day it was a very close race, but Feinstein won Los Angeles County, which may have pulled her ahead. Her sizable win in the nine-county San Francisco Bay Area may also be credited to her slim statewide victory. A large number of absentee ballots left the results in doubt for over two weeks. On November 18, Senator Feinstein declared victory. At that time, she was ahead by 147,404 votes, with only 156,210 remaining uncounted ballots.<ref name="Feinstein declared victory">{{cite news |author=B. Drummond Ayres Jr. |date=November 19, 1994 |title=THE NEW CONGRESS: CALIFORNIA; Feinstein Claims Victory in Senate Race |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/19/us/the-new-congress-california-feinstein-claims-victory-in-senate-race.html}}</ref> Huffington had not conceded at that point, saying that there was evidence of voter fraud and calling for an investigation. He had already filed a legal complaint, which had already been dismissed.<ref name="Feinstein declared victory"/> As of December 23, Huffington still contended that there may have been voting fraud and had not conceded.<ref>{{cite news |author=B. Drummond Ayres Jr. |date=December 26, 1994 |title=Nov. 8 Is Long Gone, but the California Election Lingers On, and On and On |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/12/26/us/nov-8-is-long-gone-but-the-california-election-lingers-on-and-on-and-on.html}}</ref>

 The '''2020 United States Senate election in Massachusetts''' was held on November 3, 2020, to elect a member of the [[United States Senate]] to represent the [[Commonwealth of Massachusetts]], concurrently with the [[2020 U.S. presidential election]], as well as [[2020 United States Senate elections|elections]] to the United States Senate in other states, [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections|elections]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]] and various [[2020 United States elections|state and local elections]]. On September 1, incumbent Senator [[Ed Markey]] defeated U.S. Representative [[Joe Kennedy III]] in a competitive primary for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nomination and Kevin O'Connor defeated [[Shiva Ayyadurai]] for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nomination.
 
 ==Democratic primary==
 The state primary election took place on September 1, 2020.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.state.ma.us/CalendarWeb/Pages/MonthWeekCalendar.aspx |title= Election calendar|website= www.sec.state.ma.us|format=PDF|access-date=2020-08-03}}</ref> Incumbent Senator [[Ed Markey]] was challenged by U.S. Representative [[Joe Kennedy III]]. Kennedy and Markey have similar political positions, though Markey is considered more liberal on the [[NOMINATE (scaling method)|DW-Nominate]] scale.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rakich|first=Nathaniel|date=2019-09-24|title=Joe Kennedy Isn't Your Usual Upstart Primary Challenger|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/joe-kennedy-wants-to-unseat-a-senator-hes-not-your-usual-primary-challenger/|access-date=2020-09-02|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US}}</ref> An elected senator has not been defeated in a primary since [[Richard Lugar]] in [[2012 United States Senate election in Indiana|2012]], and an elected Democrat has not been defeated since [[Joe Lieberman]] in [[2006 United States Senate election in Connecticut|2006]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Jacobson|first=Louis|title=Markey vs. Kennedy: Welcome to the most unusual Senate primary in decades – Sabato's Crystal Ball|url=https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/markey-vs-kennedy-welcome-to-the-most-unusual-senate-primary-in-decades/|access-date=2020-08-30|language=en-US}}. [[Arlen Specter]], who was elected as a Republican but switched parties to Democratic, was defeated in [[2010 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania|2010]] during his first Democratic primary.</ref>

Mark DeSaulnier's condition worsens, now listed as critical|work = [[East Bay Times]]|date = March 21, 2020|accessdate = March 21, 2020|last = Gartell|first = Nate}}</ref>
+
+In May 2016, DeSaulnier announced that he had been diagnosed with [[chronic lymphocytic leukemia]] in 2015, and had undergone chemotherapy.<ref name="cancer">{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/la-pol-ca-desaulnier-cancer-20160506-snap-story.html|title=U.S. Rep. Mark DeSaulnier says blood cancer won't keep him from seeking another term|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]].com|accessdate=May 7, 2016|date=May 6, 2016|author=Sarah D. Wire}}</ref> While the cancer was described as incurable, DeSaulnier said he would still seek re-election.<ref name="cancer"/>
+
+On March 13, 2020, DeSaulnier was hospitalized in [[Washington, D.C.]], for a rib fracture sustained during a run, as well as for pneumonia.<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/03/16/congressman-mark-desaulnier-hospitalized-in-running-fall/|title = Congressman Mark DeSaulnier hospitalized in running fall|work = [[The Mercury News]]|date = March 16, 2020|accessdate = March 21, 2020|last = Hurd|first = Rick}}</ref> On March 21, it was announced that his health had declined, and he was reported as being in [[medical state|critical condition]].<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2020/03/21/rep-mark-desaulnier-declines-to-critical-condition-in-pneumonia-fight-1268645|title = Rep. Mark DeSaulnier declines to 'critical condition' in pneumonia fight|work = [[Politico]]|date = March 21, 2020|accessdate = March 21, 2020|last = White|first = Jeremy B.}}</ref> He steadily recovered, and was released from the hospital on May 4.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Rep. Mark DeSaulnier released after nearly two months in hospital|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/rep-mark-desaulnier-released-after-nearly-two-months-in-hospital|last=Borenstein|first=Daniel|date=2020-05-04|website=The Mercury News|language=en-US|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-05-27}}</ref>

[[University of California, Los Angeles]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]], [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]) |website = {{url|correa.house.gov|House website}} }} '''Jose Luis Correa'''{{cite news|url=http://taxdollars.ocregister.com/2011/06/03/debt-collector-erroneously-garnishes-oc-lawmakers-wages/84371/|title=Debt collector erroneously garnishes OC lawmaker's wages|work=[[The Orange County Register]]|date=June 3, 2011|last=Joseph|first=Brian}} {{IPAc-en|k|ə|ˈ|r|eɪ|ə}} (born January 24, 1958 in [[Anaheim, California]]) is an American politician who is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|CA|46}}. A [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], he served as a member of the [[California State Senate]], representing the 34th Senate district. -A graduate of [[Anaheim High School]], Correa earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Economics]] from [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State Fullerton]] as well as a [[Juris Doctor]] and [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]. He was an investment banker, a real estate broker, and a college instructor. +Prior to his career in politics, Correa was an investment banker, a real estate broker, and a college instructor. -==Early career== +==Early life and education== +A graduate of [[Anaheim High School]], Correa earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Economics]] from [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State Fullerton]] as well as a [[Juris Doctor]] and [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]. + +==Early political career== Correa's political career began in 1996 when he ran for the [[California State Assembly]] as the Democratic nominee in the 69th Assembly district. In a very close race, he lost to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] incumbent [[Jim Morrissey (politician)|Jim Morrissey]] by just 93 votes.{{cite news|url=https://articles.latimes.com/1996-12-06/local/me-10398_1_recount-request|title=Vote Recount Called Off by Assembly Candidate|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=December 6, 1996|last=Warren|first=Peter}} In a 1998 rematch, Correa was elected to the Assembly when he defeated Morrissey 54% to 43%.{{cite news|title=Decision '98: The Final Count|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 5, 1998}} While a member of the Assembly, Correa served on several committees and was the chair of the Committee on Business and Professions, the Public Employees, Retirement and Social Security Committee; the Select Committee on Mobile Homes; and the Select Committee on [[Marine Corps Air Station El Toro|MCAS El Toro]] Reuse. Correa was re-elected to the Assembly twice but was forced from office by California's [[term limit]]s law, which restricts members from serving more than three two-year terms. In 2004, he campaigned for and was elected to the [[Orange County Board of Supervisors]], becoming the first Democrat to serve on the board since 1987.{{cite news|title=Orange County Elections|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 3, 2004|last=Weikel|first=Dan}} He represented the first district, which includes the cities of Garden Grove, Santa Ana, and Westminster as well as unincorporated areas of the county including [[Midway City, California|Midway City]]. ==State Senate== [[File:Lou Correa.jpg|thumb|left|Correa during his time in the state Senate]] In January 2006, Correa entered the race for the Democratic Party nomination for the California State Senate 34th district, a seat vacated by termed out Democratic State Senator [[Joe Dunn (California)|Joe Dunn]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/-193239--.html|title=34th Senate race likely to get heated, expensive|work=[[The Orange County Register]]|date=January 26, 2006|last=Quach|first=Hanh Kim}} After defeating Assemblyman [[Tom Umberg]] in the contested June primary, Correa faced off against Republican Assemblywoman [[Lynn Daucher]] in the November general election. In yet another close race, Correa won the election with a margin of victory of 1,392 votes.{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/correa-188354-daucher-district.html|title=The Hot Senate Race|work=[[The Orange County Register]]|date=October 24, 2006|last=Wisckol|first=Martin}} Correa was sworn into the California State Senate on December 4, 2006.

 Following is a table of '''United States presidential elections in Ohio''', ordered by year. Since its admission to statehood in 1803, [[Ohio]] has participated in every U.S. presidential election.
 
 Ohio is considered a [[swing state]], being won by either the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] or [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidates from election to election. As a swing state, Ohio is usually targeted by both major-party campaigns, especially in competitive elections.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-odds-of-an-electoral-college-popular-vote-split-are-increasing/|title=The Odds of an Electoral College-Popular Vote Split Are Increasing|date=2016-11-01|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221013034/http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-odds-of-an-electoral-college-popular-vote-split-are-increasing/|archive-date=December 21, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Pivotal in the election of [[1888 United States presidential election|1888]], Ohio has been a regular swing state since 1980.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/02/arts/02camp.html Trolling the Campuses for Swing-State Votes] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528014334/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/02/arts/02camp.html |date=May 28, 2015 }}, Julie Salamon, "[[The New York Times]]", October 2, 2004</ref><ref>[http://www.slate.com/id/2108640/ Game Theory for Swingers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201225851/http://www.slate.com/id/2108640/ |date=February 1, 2011 }}, Jordan Ellenberg, "[[Slate.com]]", October 25, 2004</ref>
